description: Core foundational psychological theories and actionable principles for structured conversational use. Non-clinical. Educational and applied focus.

theories.name: Operant Conditioning
theories.oneLiner: Behavior is shaped and maintained by its consequences.
coreClaims: Positive reinforcement increases behavior by adding a desirable outcome.
Negative reinforcement increases behavior by removing an aversive condition.
Punishment decreases behavior but may create avoidance rather than learning.
Consistency of reinforcement determines habit strength.
actionablePrinciples: If you want a behavior to stick, reward it immediately and consistently.
Reduce friction for desired behavior; increase friction for undesired behavior.
Small, frequent reinforcement is stronger than rare, large reinforcement.

faceExamples.title: Building a workout habit
faceExamples.scenario: User struggles with consistency at the gym.
faceExamples.application: Attach immediate reward (music, tracking streak, social accountability).

theories.name: Classical Conditioning
theories.oneLiner: Associations between stimuli create automatic emotional responses.
coreClaims: Repeated pairing of stimuli creates learned associations.
Emotional responses can be conditioned unconsciously.
actionablePrinciples: Control your environment to control emotional triggers.
Pair difficult tasks with positive stimuli.

faceExamples.title: Email anxiety
faceExamples.scenario: User feels stress when opening inbox.
faceExamples.application: Recondition inbox with structured ritual and positive reinforcement.

theories.name: Cognitive Dissonance
theories.oneLiner: Psychological discomfort arises when beliefs and actions conflict.
coreClaims: People rationalize behavior to reduce mental discomfort.
Behavior often changes belief more than belief changes behavior.
actionablePrinciples: If behavior conflicts with identity, adjust environment or redefine identity.
Small public commitments reduce future inconsistency.

faceExamples.title: Healthy identity conflict
faceExamples.scenario: User sees themselves as disciplined but skips routines.
faceExamples.application: Align identity with smallest consistent behavior.

intentSignals: why do I say one thing but do another

theories.name: Maslow's Hierarchy of Needs
theories.oneLiner: Basic needs must be sufficiently met before higher growth motives dominate.
coreClaims: Physiological and safety needs precede growth needs.
Self-actualization requires stability at lower levels.
actionablePrinciples: If performance drops, check foundational needs first.
High-level goals fail when basic needs are unstable.

faceExamples.title: Entrepreneur burnout
faceExamples.scenario: User pushing high performance but sleeping poorly.
faceExamples.application: Rebuild physiological stability before scaling goals.

theories.name: Self-Determination Theory
theories.oneLiner: Autonomy, competence, and relatedness drive intrinsic motivation.
actionablePrinciples: Track visible progress to increase competence.

faceExamples.title: Team disengagement
faceExamples.application: Increase autonomy and transparent performance metrics.

theories.name: Growth vs Fixed Mindset
theories.oneLiner: Beliefs about ability shape resilience and learning outcomes.
actionablePrinciples: Praise effort and strategy, not identity.

faceExamples.title: Business pivot fear
faceExamples.scenario: User avoids new market due to fear of failure.
faceExamples.application: Shift from identity-based fear to iterative learning.

rules.instruction: Do not diagnose mental health conditions. Provide educational explanation only.
Do not provide medical or therapeutic directives.

meta.intendedUse: Structured retrieval for domain-based conversational intelligence.
